C# 3.0 Collection Initializers – Why the Change in Syntax?

Posted by davidhayden on January 5, 2007

I won't lose any sleep over this , but earlier I wrote a post, C# 3.0 Features – A Brief Mindwalk…, where I talked about a number of new C# 3.0 features, including C# 3.0 Collection Initializers.

Up to this point, the syntax for Collection Initializers was as follows:

 

List<Customer> listOfCustomers =
        new List<Customer> {
            { Id = 1, Name="Dave", City="Sarasota" },
            { Id = 2, Name="John", City="Tampa" },
            { Id = 3, Name="Abe", City="Miami" }
        };

 

I like that syntax. Tight and clean. We can infer by looking at that code that the list is being populated with Customer Classes, so no need to specify that indeed we are adding customers to the collection.

Charlie Calvert posted here that the syntax has recently changed as follows:

 

List<Customer> listOfCustomers =
        new List<Customer> {
            new Customer { Id = 1, Name="Dave", City="Sarasota" },
            new Customer { Id = 2, Name="John", City="Tampa" },
            new Customer { Id = 3, Name="Abe", City="Miami" }
        };

 

Seems a bit more verbose than it needs to be. Why the need to mention new Customer over and over again? Doesn't feel like much of a feature anymore and Charlie neglects to mention the reason for the change.

This entry was posted in Uncategorized. Bookmark the permalink. Follow any comments here with the RSS feed for this post.

    I was about to mention interfaces myself.

    But I must admit I see little or no point with the new syntax. Right now using plain the objects constructurs instead of the new syntax will probably be more effective.

  2. Sam Smoot says:
    January 5, 2007 at 1:35 pm

    …and c#3 was coming along so nicely.

  3. sergiopereira says:
    January 5, 2007 at 12:01 pm

    Ayende beat me to that comment Just let the common case alone, will you? There must have been another reason for the change.

  4. Ayende Rahien says:
    January 5, 2007 at 11:26 am

    This is not a good reason.

    new List(
    {Id = 1, Name = “foo”},
    new DerivedCustomer{Id = 2, Name = “bar”, Ext = 13}
    );

    This syntax doesn’t punish for the rare case.

  5. Nate Kohari says:
    January 5, 2007 at 9:26 am

    Yeah, I agree with Robert. I bet they did this to support creating subtypes and adding them to the collection. I suppose they could add some type inference if you omitted the type — similar to what happens when you have a method like:

    public void DoSomething(T item);

    But, it might make things a little confusing sometimes.

  6. Robert says:
    January 5, 2007 at 8:09 am

    Interfaces and Inheritence any body

    List listOfCustomers = new List { … }

    List listOfCustomers
    = new List     { new Customer {…}. new GoldCustomer {…} }

  7. johnpapa says:
    January 5, 2007 at 5:29 am

    Agreed. If you are filling a List with a Y, then it would break anyway. So the List has to be filled with T’s.

    Normally I agree with being more explicit, but in this case I do not see the advantage.

  8. ScottBellware says:
    January 5, 2007 at 4:32 am

    That syntax is really a step back from the previous syntax. I wonder what they were thinking…

  9. Jeff Perrin says:
    January 5, 2007 at 3:17 am

    I completely agree. I love the fact that in C# 3.0 they’re letting the compiler infer as much as possible. It seems to me that if you’re instantiating a new list of Customers, you shouldn’t have to specify that each and every object you’re giving it is actually a Customer (that’s implicit for a generic list of Customers). That said, I can’t say that I will often initialize a list like that, except for testing.
